messageBody:
junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> Ilja Preuss wrote:
>>> in Java
>>> everything that's public is published, whether you want it to be or
>>> not.
>>
>> That's not true. Even in Sun's libraries, there are public classes
>> and methods in com.sun packages, which per convention aren't
>> *published*. If you use them, you do so at your own peril.
>
>
> And guess what? People use them, even though they aren't supposed to.

And guess what? They might do so for good reasons, while being aware of the
fact that what they do is rather fragile.

I even access a private field in a thirdparty class once in a year, using
reflection. I always do that because it's the best option available.

> Hell, I even wrote a book whose primary focus
> was on documenting, explaining, and teaching people to use the sun
> classes!

You hopefully warned them that they shouldn't blame Sun for not supporting
the API in the next version of the library.

> If gentlemen's agreements were sufficient to enforce constraints on
> usage, we never would have had to invent access protection in the
> first place.

Guess what, Smalltakers live very well with "private" being not more than a
comment, for decades now.

> public == published in Java. I certainly wish it were
> otherwise, but sadly that's not the case.

With your reasoning it seems to me that even private == published in Java,
because private doesn't hold me from accessing a member, if I really want
to. Might just be me, though.

Cheers, Ilja
